messages.body:
Feb 21 2008
 
Dear Miss Larry,

I'm interested to know how my name got on a Christian website, but no matter.

I would love to offer assistance.  I am not Christian, but I do know the Bible.  Is this a problem?

Sincerely,
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

("Ben Zona" is Hebrew for "son of a prostitute" and is alternately a profanity and slang for something really really great. "Rodef Bubbameissah" is Hebrew/Yiddish meaning loosely "chaser of tall tales".)

messages.body:
Mar 2, 2008
B"H

My dear Mrs. Larry,

It is in the nature of my profession that attracted me to your proposal to begin with.  I do much charitable work in the community here that crosses all boundaries.   For example, there's my very successful Tots Without Torsos campaign, and fortunately, thanks to my efforts many of them are able to get a head in life.  I imagine a lot of this money would be earmarked though for Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah - they just love a good story.

I'm not sure I'm all that keen in getting a consignment of what I understand from your messages as a box full of cash.  Just how much money are we talking here?  I deal with thousands of dollars daily, and I don't think that I've ever made a cash transaction.  You've obviously got email over in the Ivory Coast ; surely you have Internet banking?  I'd also bet that there are some legal issues involved.  

Now, as for the matter of Samuel, I of course am happy to take him in, but I'm afraid that as a born again Christian he might feel a little left out around the Shabbas table.  My intention would be start a proper Jewish conversion.  I hope this is OK with you.  Is he circumcised?  That would be a start.  His Bible school will do him well to begin with; but of course as with all my children he would be required to do a more rigorous Talmudic education.  We'll look after him well after your death, don't you worry.  My wife Chaya Mushka is a wonderful mother to our 27 children. 

One thing that bothers me about this, and please forgive me if I'm way off base here, but could I possibly get some identification?  I mean, I accept money from a lot of anonymous donours, but I've yet to take in someone's son.

Sincerely,
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

messages.body:
Mar 4, 2008
B"H 

My dear Mrs. Larry, or is it Mrs. William, or is it Mrs. Williams, 

It's always nice to correspond with a fine, charitable woman such as yourself.  Thank you for your correspondence thus far.  
 
Please don't take this the wrong way, as I have the utmost respect for a fellow pious person as you seem to be.  I don't mean any offence, but as a "man of the cloth" so to speak, I know my fair share about certain religions.  I don't know much about Animism or the obscure tribal religions of the world, but if there's one thing I'm polished up on, it's Christianity.  I have many Christian friends, fine people all.  In fact, one of my closest friends, Troy Glaus, became a Cardinal very recently. 

And you do say that Samuel has been circumcised according to the Christian religion.  My dear Mrs. Larry/William/Williams - what is your surname, anyway? - if Christians were mandated to be circumcised, my people would have had a much easier time over the last 2000 years.  How did Samuel come to be circumcised?  

I also hope what I'm about to say isn't a deal-breaker.  The term "Rabbi" is a title for a Jewish religious leader.  Although we have close ties with members of our Moslem brothers, Samuel will find little solace in knowing the difference between shahadah and  sadaqah. 

As far as identification goes, well, something with the correct spelling of your name at the very least is a good start.  If I'm to be your "family partner", I will need a letter from your doctor as well detailing the full extent of your illness and your prognosis.   

I'm sure once we get this religious stuff out of the way, we can let the mullah come rolling in. 

Sincerely, 
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona 
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

messages.subject: answer my questions, first
messages.body:
B"H

Hello, Mrs. William or Mrs. Williams,

How lovely to hear from you again.  You wouldn't understand if I told you how much I look forward to your missives.

Who is the lady in the picture?  Is this you?  I'm so sorry about your ex-son, Larry.  Your son and husband were both named Larry?  How many sons do you have?  

So sorry to hear that you're still in the hospital.  I will say a special misheberach (prayer for the sick) for you in shul on Shabbat under the name of Shakranis bas Tipshiyah.  

However, although the Talmud states: "Doubt cannot override a certainty", I fail to see any certainties.  Before I contact the security company, you must address the following:

1.  The age of Samuel.  
2.  The auspices under which Samuel became circumcised..
3.  Your full name.  I'm very confused as to whether you're a singular or a plural, as you're signature and your email name don't match.
4.   A letter from your oncologist detailing the full extent of your illness and prognosis.  

As stated previously, once my concerns are assuaged I'm sure you'll be rewarded with exactly what you deserve.  

Sincerely,
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

messages.body:
Mar 18, 2008
B"H

Hello, Mrs. William:

What a relief to hear from you!  I was expecting the worst, so I'm very glad to hear that you're OK.  Are you still in hospital?  

I'm a fairly good judge of character, and to me you seem like an honest, brave woman, and a good mother to Samuel.  I must ask of you, though, to put yourself in my shoes.  After seeing my name on a Christian website (which one, if I may ask?), out of the blue, someone from Africa contacts me asking me to distribute her money.  I have no proof that the money exists, any identification from you, aside from a picture of a woman in her mid-20s, nor a single answer to my simple questions below.  Scroll down on this message:  you can still see them if you don't remember.  

I will be frank with you.  As I mentioned in a previous correspondence, I've got a good number of children, so I'm quite used to being ignored.  It doesn't necessarily mean I like it, especially when there's a great deal of money involved here.  The way I see it, is that the ball in completely in your court; it's not my money yet to distribute, and you're the one that doesn't have long to go.  It really is then in your best interest to answer what I need.  At the very very least, please get me that doctor's note, and I'm willing to proceed.

I'm happy to contact the security company, but please know that I am unwilling to fully proceed with this matter until I get some of the simple facts down.

Can I also get Samuel's email address?  I would like to contact him so I can get to know the boy a little better.

messages.body:
Mar 21, 2008
B"H

Hello, Shmuli!  How nice to hear from you.  Are you enjoying Bible school?  Make your "old man" proud.  My wife, Chaya Mushka and your future brothers and sisters can't wait to meet you.  None of them have even met someone from your part of the world.  It's all very exciting!  Please send me a picture!  I don't even know how old you are because your mother hasn't answered me yet.  

I've got a bit of an odd request.  You may or may not know, but in our religion prescribes all males to be circumcised.  Your mother did tell us that you were circumcised according to your custom.  Respectfully, could you perhaps send me a picture of your  circumcision job?  If it isn't sufficient, it's not really a big deal; either way we would only need to draw a small, ritual amount of blood.  To make necessary arrangements on our end, I would need to know what I'm dealing with. Don't worry: I'm a qualified "mohel" (qualified to performs circumcisions).    

Do you have any questions for us?  

Sincerely, 
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona 
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah
 
p.s. Little Shayndl has a question for you:  What language do you speak?  (She's very good with languages..)

Mar 23, 2008
B"H

Hello Shmuli!   I'm interested to know what you know about my religion.  What do they teach you at Bible school?  

I don't so much need your "ordinary" picture so much as some proof indicating that you are who you really are:  I'm looking for a picture of your circumcision, not a head shot.  If as you say you don't have the picture with you, by all means go and get it.  Circumcisions are done according to strict laws and I need to make sure that yours was done properly lest I save you from unnecessary pain and hardship after you arrive.    

I asked a few simple questions of your ; I can understand that she would have trouble contacting me because of her illness.  We are talking about quite a lot of money here and there's a lot at stake as far as me taking you into my home.  How old are you?   

Can you please get a doctor's note for me outlining your  condition and prognosis?    

Nevertheless, the troubling part about the relationship I have with the William family is that neither you nor your  have yet answered a single one of my questions.  I don't even know your  first name.  Part of my job is to act as a grief counsellor for my congregants and I do a lot of work in palliative care units, so I'm aware that your mind (not to mention your ) is probably quite scattered because of your .  I have indeed contacted the security company, but have indicated to them and to your  that I'm not willing to continue this transaction without some of my fundamental questions answered first.

messages.body:
Mar 25, 2008
B"H

Hi, Shmuli!  

I wouldn't expect you to keep a picture of your circumcision lying around.  We don't really take pictures of circumcisions right after it happens.  The proud parents, yes - I have pictures at all 14 of my boys' circumcisions - and of course the extended family and friends, but it's considered bad form to take pictures of the actual surgery.  It's pretty gory, as you can imagine.    

What I'm after is a picture of you, as you look today, with the visual proof that you are who you are and you had done what you say you had done.  

Looking forward to seeing the doctor's letter now as well so we can get underway with the security company.  

Shmuli, you're a bright lad, doing well in Bible school.  You do understand this old man's predicament?    

Sincerely, 
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona 
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah  

p.s.  Shayndl is so pleased you speak French!  She's learning it at school, and hopes that you two can converse in French once you get over here.

messages.body:
Mar 26, 2008
B"H

Hi, Shmuli! 
 isn't my sister, she's my daughter.  She was gushing that she has someone to practice her French with.  I nor my wife do not speak any French - Yiddish, Hebrew, and can understand Aramaic, but no French - so Shayndl appreciates all the encouragement and attention.  Shayndl is only 12 but also learning other languages at school besides French.  I'm sure she'll be writing you again.  

Regarding your picture, this is not a difficult proposition.  Respectfully, Shmuli, can't you see what is at stake here?  Your  told me a couple of weeks ago that you were circumcised according to tradition.  I need to see not only proof that it was done, but that it was done properly.  You can leave your shirt on if you'd like but of course I will need your pants down. Include your face as well so that I know it's really you.  I understand this may be somewhat embarrassing, but it's not as if I'll be posting the pictures up on a website.   Understand that I have no use for pornography.  I am a simple, pious man, and if you are to be taken in to my house as my son, I need for you to take my religion, wholly and completely.  
  
Tell me, what is the name of the hospital your  is at?  I must send a card, or flowers, or at least give a call to.  Bikur cholim, the visiting of the sick, is a very big religious obligation.  As I cannot get to Africa , G-d will understand my acknowledgement.  I have already made donations in your  name to Sisters of St. Hubbins, an organisation providing shoes to the needy, as well as to Our Lady of Perpetual Crabs, a non-profit organisation raising awareness for people in your mother's condition.

messages.body:
Apr 2, 2008
B"H

Hi, Shmuli:

Looking back on our correspondence, I notice that there is possibly some confusion on how I expect to be addressed.  Please call me either Rabbi Zona or Dr Zona.

I take high offense to your latest missive.  I don't want to sound cold, especially in light of your circumstances, but let's talk straight.

I'm not sure what you mean by:
>>. 

My issue was not only that you steadfastly refused to expose yourself, as it were, so there's no way of me knowing the truth.  

You also said:
>>.

Again, why should I not doubt the formalities?  I have absolutely zero identification or proof that you and your  are who you say you are, let alone whether or not the money actually exists.

We seem to be going around in circles here.  For the final time, I will not contact the security company again until I see some identification.  The onus of proof is on you, Shmuli.  Of course I know you both exist - someone is writing me, after all - but 
officially I have no corroboration of this.

>> ...
You're 22 years old, right?  Let's get something else straight.  Respectfully, bubbeleh, you know bubkas..  I represent a major congregation and charitable organisation, donating millions of dollars each year to charities all around the world..  Rodef Bubbameissah is listed on NASDAQ (quote: URAFKWT) and have thousands of members internationally.  Don't advise me to try to cooperate and abide with anyone. I'm a rabbi and a mohel, but I'm also a businessman.  Keep in mind that it's your mother who contacted me to begin with.  You need me to move your money, and I've always maintained, and still maintain, that I'm happy to do so and help out.  But please don't take me for a fool.  

If you want my assistance, here's what you do:

1.   tells me she wrote you two emails that have gone unanswered.  She's a 12-year-old girl.  Answer her.  Show her you care.  Your her future brother.

2.  Get me that doctor's note.  

3.  Let me know how your  is doing.  It's your !  Keep your head clear of the money and care for the lady.  She doesn't have long to live.

4.  Stop being cagey with me when I ask you a question.  When I ask a question, it's because I want to know the answer.  Rhetorical questions don't have a place in email message, don't they?

5.  Start reading my messages.  If you don't understand something, I'm happy to explain further.

6.  You also owe me an apology, boychik. Make it a good one. 

7.  Don't even mention the words "security company" until the other 6 issues are addressed.  

Sincerely,
Dr Rabbi Ben Zona
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

messages.body:
Oct 29, 2008

B"H

Dear Shmuli,

Sometimes I ask essay questions on my tests for my students just to see what they come up with.  For some students I'd have to wade through paragraphs and paragraphs of tripe.  Oftentimes, and especially when coupled with completely illegible handwriting, I have a quick glance at the essay answers, see the sheer volume of words, and although they don't amount to much, I can see at least the thought process is working.



You, Shmuli, I'll give 8/10, as I'm deducting 2 marks for an 109-word sentence in your second paragraph, a 140-word sentence in your third paragraph, and a 90-word sentence in your last.  Unless you're David Foster Wallace, who can get away with that sort of thing, The 8 marks I'm giving you bespeaks some clear thoughts on your behalf, even though I can't honestly make heads nor tails out of your answer.  That, and I'm a bit biased because you're practically my son.



Now that we've got the guardianship issues sorted, I need you to tell me about what you learned in Bible school.  I hope you specialised in the Old Testament; not much call for knowledge of the other one around my Shabbas table.

B"H

Dear Shmuli,

How very timely.  Lech Lecha was this week's parsha.  I have an interesting question, and am curious to know your opinion, and of course, what you learned in Bible school.  Knowing your lack of propensity to handle multiple questions in one email, I'll even keep this to one question:



Notice when you quoted Genesis 12 10-20 Went to Egypt.  While it is true that Abraham and Sarah did experience famine in Canaan - the reason they went to Egypt - and considering that Abraham was commanded by G-d to go to Canaan, should he not have trusted G-d enough to get through the famine, especially in light of conceiving a plan to fool the Egyptians by exposing Sarah to potential danger?


I want a good answer, not necessarily correct, but one that's thought out properly.  I need to make the argument to the Interior Ministry that we have a potential Bible student.  Coming into Israel, and thus gaining Israeli citizenship, is not like gaining citizenship for any other country.  I know when coming to Australia you must go 3 rounds with a grey kangaroo, Canada makes you pledge allegiance to the Toronto Maple Leafs, and what with security as it is nowadays, Americans make you volunteer for 6 months as a Walmart greeter.  With Israel, you must know the Bible back to front, which is good news for you going to Bible school and all.



I also want to see if your  investment in sending you to Bible school was worth her trouble and no doubt large cost, though it escapes me that someone who needs to beg for food and Internet service can possibly maintain a . 



Sincerely,

Dr. Rabbi Ben Zona

Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah



p.s.  I'm not your Papa yet.  Please do not address me as such.

B"H

Dear Shmuli,

How very timely. Lech Lecha was this week's parsha. I have an interesting question, and am curious to know your opinion, and of course, what you learned in Bible school. Knowing your lack of propensity to handle multiple questions in one email, I'll even keep this to one question:

Notice when you quoted Genesis 12 10-20 Went to Egypt. While it is true that Abraham and Sarah did experience famine in Canaan - the reason they went to Egypt - and considering that Abraham was commanded by G-d to go to Canaan, should he not have trusted G-d enough to get through the famine, especially in light of conceiving a plan to fool the Egyptians by exposing Sarah to potential danger?

I want a good answer, not necessarily correct, but one that's thought out properly. I need to make the argument to the Interior Ministry that we have a potential Bible student. Coming into Israel, and thus gaining Israeli citizenship, is not like gaining citizenship for any other country. I know when coming to Australia you must go 3 rounds with a grey kangaroo, Canada makes you pledge allegiance to the Toronto Maple Leafs, and what with security as it is nowadays, Americans make you volunteer for 6 months as a Walmart greeter. With Israel, you must know the Bible back to front, which is good news for you going to Bible school and all.

I also want to see if your mother's investment in sending you to Bible school was worth her trouble and no doubt large cost, though it escapes me that someone who needs to beg for food and Internet service can possibly maintain a barrister.

Sincerely,
Dr. Rabbi Ben Zona
Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

p.s. I'm not your Papa yet. Please do not address me as such.

Nov 11, 2008


IP: 213.136.125.24

Dear Dr Rabbi, 

Notice the step by step procedure. Abraham drifted down and out of Canaan . And there in the pagan city of Gerar , Abraham put his life under the control of a pagan king rather than out in the countryside before God. Abraham committed the same sin of deceiving others about his wife for fear of his own life. He gave his wife to be part of another man's collection of women just so he could be safe! We should see how immoral this w as Sarah obligated to obey Abraham in these situations? From 1 Peter 3:1-6, we see that she was commended for her purity of faith. For in this way in former times the holy women also, who hoped in God, used to adorn themselves, being submissive to their own husbands. Thus Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, and you have become her children if you do what is right without being frightened by any fear" (1 Peter 3:5, 6). We have to assume that she trusted God for what would happen. We can safely assume she prayed and God delivered her out of her husband's wrong decision and immoral situation. We also must assume that if necessary she would not have willingly allowed a pagan king to touch her body. 



Was Sarah obligated to obey Abraham in these situations? From 1 Peter 3:1-6, we see that she was commended for her purity of faith. For in this way in former times the holy women also, who hoped in God, used to adorn themselves, being submissive to their own husbands. Thus Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him lord, and you have become her children if you do what is right without being frightened by any fear" (1 Peter 3:5, 6). We have to assume that she trusted God for what would happen. We can safely assume she prayed and God delivered her out of her husband's wrong decision and immoral situation. We also must assume that if necessary she would not have willingly allowed a pagan king to touch her body.



Now the LORD had said to Abram, Get you out of your country, and from your kindred, and from your father's house, to a land that I will show you:



 And I will make of you a great nation, and I will bless you, and make your name great; and you shall be a blessing And I will bless them that bless you, and curse him that curses you: and in you shall all families of the earth be blessed.  So Abram departed, as the LORD had spoken to him; and Lot went with him: and Abram was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran .  And Abram took Sarai his wife, and Lot his brother's son, and all their substance that they had gathered, and the souls that they had gotten in Haran ; and they went forth to go into the land of Canaan ; and into the land of Canaan they came.  And Abram passed through the land to the place of Sichem, to the plain of Moreh. And the Canaanite was then in the land.  And the LORD appeared to Abram, and said, to your seed will I give this land: and there built him an altar to the LORD, who appeared to him.  And he removed from there to a mountain on the east of Bethel , and pitched his tent, having Bethel on the west and Hai on the east: and there he built an altar to the LORD, and called on the name of the LORD. And Abram journeyed, going on still toward the south.  And there was a famine in the land: and Abram went down into Egypt to sojourn there; for the famine was grievous in the land.  And it came to pass, when he was come near to enter into Egypt, that he said to Sarai his wife, Behold now, I know that you are a fair woman to look on: Therefore it shall come to pass, when the Egyptians shall see you, that they shall say, This is his wife: and they will kill me, but they will save you alive. Say, I pray you, you are my sister: that it may be well with me for your sake; and my soul shall live because of you. And it came to pass, that, when Abram was come into Egypt , the Egyptians beheld the woman that she was very fair. messages.body:
Nov 20, 2008


B"H

Dear Barrister Edward, 

Funny you should mention the reputability of  - I'm beginning to have my doubts about him.  There's a separate deal I'm involved in, and  has thus far cost me a fortune, but there always seemed to be a fee for this, fee for that.  I'm not sure about his methods - West African law has me a little stumped - but he seems to be producing the necessary paperwork to get things done, so at least he's earning his coin.  Had I known how much he'd be costing I probably never would have retained him.


Which brings me back to my question about the Ivorian money laundering law that specifies this transfer fee of which you have spoken.  Where exactly on this website you sent me is this information presented? If you present me with the URL with the *exact* law and fee information, I will quite happily transfer to you the 3,000 Euros you require. 


Come to think of it, explain to me how also this African law is demanding Euros instead of the local currency?  Last time I checked, Cote D'Ivoire isn't a part of the EU.  I thought Nigeria was the only African country in the EU.  Is Cote D'Ivoire one as well?



It isn't difficult to give you my telephone number; I just choose not to give it to you.  I'd prefer this be kept on email so we have official records of everything.

messages.body:

ok shmeuil here goes the second quiz, all from the book of SHMOT (exodus)

1.  Select all that apply.  From the choices in the following list, which are punishable by death?

a.  Expectorating

b.  Extrapolating

c.  Double parking

d.  Not replacing the toilet roll

2.  Select all that apply.  What should happen if a man's ox attacks a slave?

a.  Get a new matador

b.  Much laughter ensues

c. The slave gets hurt

d.  The ox is made to wear a bell

3. What was the ephod made of?

a.  Velveeta

b.  Tofu

c.  Hummus

d.  Turpentine

4.  What part of the bull is used as a sin-offering?

a.  Big toe

b.  Large intestine

c.  Beak

d.  Gills

5.  Select all that apply.  What were the most significant spices in the oil used for anointing?

a.  Garam masala

b.  Garlic powder

c.  Old Spice

d.  Posh Spice

6.  How much is a bekah worth?

a.  approximately $4.29

b.  approximately 6 zlotys

c.  approximately 2 in the bush

d.  as much as the paper it's printed on

7.  What rested on the Mishkan by day?

a.  A dozen pigeons

b.  Tired Israelites

c.  Moses' cocker spaniel  

d.  Miriam's whites load

8.  Which was the deadliest plague brought upon the Egyptians?

a.  Yeast infection

b.  Paper cuts

c.  Post nasal drip

d.  Athlete's foot

9.  What did the Egyptians do with all the dead frogs?

a.  Fed them to their pet asps

b.  Built a new pyramid

c.  Created new loincloths

d.  Sauteed them in garlic butter

messages.body:
Dec 22, 2008

B"H

Dear Shmuli,

Good to hear from you, and Happy Hannukah!  Today we are celebrating the Festival of Lights, or alternately, the Festival of Oil.  We commemorate the time when the Temple stood, and the Jews withstood a Greek attack by the evil Antiochus.  As the Jews were hemmed in, there was only enough oil to light the menorah for one day, but by miracle, the oil lasted for eight days.  Now we celebrate by eating potato pancakes (latkes), and traditionally they are supposed to contain enough oil such that if you light one, it's supposed to burn for eight whole days.  This is another of Chaya Mushka's specialties:  we can supply our own light for a month after a batch of her crispy delights.  No wonder my oldest 6 children have become dermatologists. 



Re hiding behind identities:  It is not my barrister who you should be concerned with.  I have spoken with him many times, as have my wife and children - nearly every day I hear his voice, in fact.   may be incredibly ironic at times, but really is of no concern.  It is , Shmuli, who isn't really a barrister, but a Ghanaian Member of Parliament, as he says so himself.  I fail to see how the man can be both an MP and a barrister in two separate countries.  Just like the flatulent puffin, it smells a bit fishy.



What is the Shilo celebration?

B"H

Dear Shmuli,

Have it your way, though most of my business deals with West Africa have been handled up to now by .  I got a really good feeling from their name, which is how I got on to them in the first place.  It's a name that just rolls off the tongue - Odamwata Fukwichua.  So authentic.  I don't speak any African languages, but I find the name so meaningful, and certainly I would think, and still think, it applies well to you, your dearly departed mother, and anyone associated with you.


I understand your trepidation of dealing with another country, but I certainly wasn't happy with your previous choice of barristers.  I've decided to make it easy on you.  I've contacted a * at Belanger & Associés.  I asked him what needs to get done for these modalities.  He seems to think it's fairly straightforward, so I don't think he'll cost too much.  Certainly it's a reputable firm - I had a good look at their website - and I don't have to worry about potential scammers posing as lawyers posing as Ghanaian Members of Parliament like "Barrister ", if that was even his real name. 


 is awaiting your call - I haven't told him many details as I respected the confidentiality of this transaction.  You can contact him on (225) 24 20 64 30 or visit him in person at 9, Boulevard Latrille, Abidjan-Cocody.  Is that near you?


Sincerely,

Dr. Rabbi Ben Zona

Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

I don't speak any African languages, but I find the name so meaningful, and certainly I would think, and still think, it applies well to you, your dearly departed mother, and anyone associated with you.

I understand your trepidation of dealing with another country, but I certainly wasn't happy with your previous choice of barristers. I've decided to make it easy on you. messages.body:
Jan 27, 2009

Barrister Hamza,



I am Dr. Rabbi Ben Zona.  Your esteemed colleague  apparently has referred you on to my son-to-be , who no doubt has presented himself to your chambers as a lost soul.


I can certainly vouch for him as indeed being a lost soul, not too bright, not too respectful, nor altogether sincere come to think of it, though I imagine he's been hit hard by having to scrounge around refugee camps for a bit of change to spend at Internet cafes.  What of youth these days? 



Onto business.  As you've probably discerned from , I'm a man who prefers only to work via email.  It also looks as if young  has any cash on hand, so it looks like I'll be shelling out for something.  I refuse to pay:


- for any services to be rendered in advance;

- any fees to grease official palms;

- any "miscellaneous" or "administrative fees";

- any demurrage fees to storage companies; and

- anyone who works at a bank or a storage company who holds a doctorate of any kind.



Above all, I will not pay anyone without an official invoice. If you are uncomfortable with these terms, I will revert back to communication with .

I anticipate your most urgent response.

Sincerely,

Dr. Rabbi Ben Zona

Congregation Rodef Bubbameissah

B"H

 

Shmuli,

 

Happy Purim!  It is the time of year when we are all first reflective of what could have been, and then completely celebratory for what has happened.  Would you believe me if I had a shpiel at shul and I told the congregants all about you? Much mirth had ensued, I can tell you.  Naming of my youngest, er, "creation" after your  certainly fit in with the day's theme.  

 

I told you  patience wasn't his strong point.  If you really want the paperwork to be moving, you better start answering is questions and concerns in a timely manner.  At the outset, I'd suggest a nice long apology letter, like you really mean it, would do the trick.   likes a lot of grovelling, and why wouldn't he, he's a government official. Between you and me, I'm not sure that these government officials are on completely on the up and up anyway.  You didn't hear it from me, but I think he's on the take, if you know what I mean.

messages.body:
Mar 14, 2009


B"H

 

Hi Shmuli,

 

I saw the most excellent movie yesterday: "A Beautiful Mind."  Have you ever seen it?  Very inspiring.  What I found the most incredible is that the three main protagonists in the movie were made up!  Completely real in the eyes of the main character, and of course, to the viewing audience, which is what made the movie so excellent.  Can you imagine?  There you are, quietly trying to accomplish a top-secret, highly confidential job, and the three people that you most trust to help get the job done are fabricated?  I mean, how would you feel, especially when if you looked back for clues and in retrospect just seemed so obvious?   

 

Shmuli, I understand the desperation you feel (albeit not the words of your message) right now.  Just remember you're sitting on a gold mine, and it's money that though you can't presently access it, you will at some point.  I've been trying for lo the past several months to organise legal representation and government assistance, but I think everything right now rests on you communicating with .  Without the help needed from the bureaucracy that is the Israeli Interior Ministry, I'm afraid I'm of no use helping to get you into the country.  I haven't spoken to  in quite a few weeks so I don't know where your case is at.

 

In the meantime, I've sent another $1,000 for your troubles through my usual channels (take note, ).  I'll see that  delivers this to you promptly.

Without the help needed from the bureaucracy that is the Israeli Interior Ministry, I'm afraid I'm of no use helping to get you into the country. In the meantime, I've sent another $1,000 for your troubles through my usual channels (take note, Owata). I'll see that Owata delivers this to you promptly.

messages.body:
March 17, 2009


GREETINGS, ALEX SHEMULI,

I have been waiting for you since to contact me for your (FIRST CLASS PLANE TICKET TO LAGOS) 

Then I went and mail the ticket with DHL COURRIER SERVICE, West Africa,What you have to do

now is to contact the DHL COURRIER SERVICE as soon as possible to know when

they will deliver your package to you because of the expiring date.

The only money you will send to the DHL COURRIER SERVICE to deliver your

Draft direct to your postal Address in your country is ( 362.00 US Dollars)

only being for the Security Keeping Fee of the Courier Company so far.

Again, don't be deceived by anybody to pay any other money except 362.00  US

Dollars.I would have paid for the security keeping fees but they said no

because they don't know when you will contact them and in case of demurrage.

For your information, I have paid for the delivering Charges, Insurance

premium and Clearance Certificate Fee of the TICKET showing that it is not

FOR DELIVERY OF DRUGS OR TO COMMIT AL QUADA TERRORIST ATTACK OK.

You have to contact the DHL COURIER SERVICE now for the delivery of your

Draft with this information bellow;

Contact Person: Dr. Uluklaka Nasol 

Email Address: uluklakanasol@live.com

             

Finally, make sure that you reconfirm your Full Name,Postal address() and

Direct telephone number to them again to avoid any mistake on the Delivery

and ask them to give you the tracking number to enable you track your

package over there and know when it will get to your address.

Let me repeat again, try to contact them as soon as you receive this mail to

avoid any further delay and remember to pay them their Security Keeping fee

of 362.00 US Dollars for their immediate action. You should also let me know

through email as soon as you receive your TICKET.


Yours Faithfully,

BARRISTER O. DIKEDJUA (OWATA)
ODAMWATA FUKWICHUA CHAMBERS
